info.title: Butler API documentation
info.description:
Butler is a microservice that provides add-on features to Qlik Sense Enterprise on Windows.
Butler offers both a REST API and things like failed reload notifications etc.

This page contains the API documentation. Full documentation is available at https://butler.ptarmiganlabs.com

get.summary: Get an array of all enabled API endpoints.
get.description:
Get an array of all enabled API endpoints, using the key names from the Butler config file.

Note: Endpoints are enabled/disabled in the Butler main configuration file.

200.description: Enabled API enpooints.

get.summary: Converts strings from base62 to base16.
get.description: Converts strings from base62 to base16.

parameters.description: The base62 encoded string that should be converted to base16
parameters.name: base62

200.description: Base conversion successful.

base62.description: The base62 encoded string that should be converted to base16

get.summary: Converts strings from base16 to base62.
get.description: Converts strings from base16 to base62.

parameters.description: The base16 encoded string that should be converted to base62
parameters.name: base16

200.description: Base conversion successful.

base62.description: The base62 encoded string that should be converted to base16

get.summary: Tests if Butler is alive and responding
get.description: Tests if Butler is alive and responding

200.description: Butler is alive and well.

put.summary: Copy file(s) between well defined, approved locations.
put.description:
Copying of files is only posttible between pre-approved directories.
Defining approved source and destination directories is done in Butler's config file.

If the source directory contains subdirectories, these will be copied too.

toFile.description: Name of destination file. Can be different from source file name, if needed.

overwrite.description: Controls whether destination file should be overwritten if it already exists. Note that the copy operation will silently fail if you set this to false and the destination exists. Defaults to false.

preserveTimestamp.description: When true, the timestamp of the source file(s) will be preserved on the destination file(s). When false, timestamp behaviour is OS-dependent. Defaults to false.

toFile.description: Name of destination file. Can be different from source file name, if needed.

overwrite.description: Controls whether destination file should be overwritten if it already exists. Note that the copy operation will silently fail if you set this to false and the destination exists. Defaults to false.

preserveTimestamp.description: When true, the timestamp of the source file(s) will be preserved on the destination file(s). When false, timestamp behaviour is OS-dependent. Defaults to false.

403.description: No approved fromDir/toDir for file copy.

schema.description: No approved fromDir/toDir for file copy.

put.summary: Move file(s) between well defined, approved locations.
put.description:
Moving of files is only posttible between pre-approved directories.
Defining approved source and destination directories is done in Butler's config file.

If the source directory contains subdirectories, these will be moved too.

toFile.description: Name of destination file. Can be different from source file name, if needed.

overwrite.description: Controls whether destination file should be overwritten if it already exists. Defaults to false.

toFile.description: Name of destination file. Can be different from source file name, if needed.

overwrite.description: Controls whether destination file should be overwritten if it already exists. Defaults to false.

403.description: No approved fromDir/toDir for file copy.

schema.description: No approved fromDir/toDir for file copy.

delete.summary: Delete file(s) in well defined, approved locations.
delete.description:
It is only possible to delete files in pre-approved directories, or subdirectories thereof.
Defining approved directories is done in Butler's config file.

deleteFile.description: Name of file to be deleted. Use forward/backward slashes in paths as needed, depending on whether Butler runs on Windows/non-Windows platform.

400.description: "Required parameter missing" or "File requested for delete not found".

schema.description: "Required parameter missing" or "File requested for delete not found".

403.description: No approved directory matches the delete request.

schema.description: No approved directory matches the delete request.

post.summary: Creates a directory in designated QVD directory.
post.description: Creates a directory in QVD directory (which is defined in Butler's config file).

post.summary: Creates a directory anywhere in the file system.
post.description:
If the directory already exists nothing will happen.
If permissions don't allow a directory to be created, or if the path is invalid, an error will be returned.

directory.description: Path to directory that should be created. Can be a relative or absolute path.

200.description: Array of all namespaces.

get.summary: Get the value associated with a key, in a specific namespace.

200.description: Key and it's associated value and metadata returned.

schema.description: Key and it's associated value and metadata returned.

value.description: Value stored in the key-value pair.

400.description: "Namespace or key not found" or "Required parameter missing".

schema.description: "Namespace or key not found" or "Required parameter missing".

post.summary: Create a new key-value pair in the specified namespace.
post.description:
If the specified key already exists it will be overwritten.

If the posted data has a TTL, it will start counting when the post occur.
I.e. if a previouly posted key also had a TTL, it will be replace with the most recent TTL.

ttl.description: Time to live = how long (milliseconds) the key-value pair should exist before being automatically deleted

value.description: Value stored in the key-value pair.

ttl.description: Time-to-live for the key-value pair. 0 if no ttl was set, otherwise in milliseconds.

delete.summary: Delete a namespace and all key-value pairs in it.

get.summary: Checks if a key exists in a namespace.
get.description: Returns true if the specified key exists, otherwise false.

200.description: Key exist/no-exist returned, together with the data if the does exist.

schema.description: Key exist/no-exist returned, together with the data if the does exist.

keyExists.description: true/false flag indicating whether the specified key exists in the given namespace.

value.description: Value stored in the key-value pair.

delete.summary: Delete a key-value pair in a specific namespace.

400.description: "Namespace or key not found" or "Required parameter missing".

schema.description: "Namespace or key not found" or "Required parameter missing".

get.summary: Retrieve a list of all keys present in the specified namespace.

parameters.description: Name of namespace whose keys should be returned.
parameters.name: namespace

200.description: Object containing namespace name + list of allkeys in the namespace.

schema.description: Object containing namespace name + list of allkeys in the namespace.

put.summary: Publish a message to a MQTT topic.

topic.description: Topic to which message should be published.

message.description: The message is a generic text string and can thus contain anything that can be represented in a string, including JSON, key-value pairs, plain text etc.

post.description: This endpoint posts metrics to the New Relic metrics API.

type.description: Metric type. Valid options are count, distribution, gauge, summary.

timestamp.description: The metric's start time in Unix time. Uses UTC time zone. This field also support seconds, microseconds, and nanoseconds. However, the data will be converted to milliseconds for storage and query. Metrics reported with a timestamp older than 48 hours ago or newer than 24 hours from the time they are reported are dropped by New Relic. If left empty Butler will use the current time as timestamp.

interval.description: The length of the time window. Required for count and summary metric types.

attributes.description: Dimensions that will be associated with the metric.

202.description: Data accepted and sent to New Relic.

schema.description: Data accepted and sent to New Relic.

get.summary: Get all information available for existing schedule(s).
get.description:
If a schedule ID is specified using a query parameter (and there exists a schedule with that ID), information about that schedule will be returned.
If no schedule ID is specified, all schedules will be returned.

200.description: Schedule successfully retrieved.

cronSchedule.description:
5 or 6 position cron schedule.

If 6 positions used, the leftmost position represent seconds.
If 5 positions used, leftmost position is minutes.

The example schedule will trigger at 00 and 30 minutes past 6:00 on Mon-Fri.

timezone.description: Time zone the schedule should use. Ex "Europe/Stockholm".

qlikSenseTaskId.description: ID of Qlik Sense task that should be started when schedule triggers.

startupState.description: If set to "start" or "started", the schedule will be started upon creation. Otherwise it will remain in stopped state.

tags.description: Can be used to categorise schedules.

lastKnownState.description: Last known state (started/stopped) for the schedule.

cronSchedule.description:
5 or 6 position cron schedule.

If 6 positions used, the leftmost position represent seconds.
If 5 positions used, leftmost position is minutes.

The example schedule will trigger at 00 and 30 minutes past 6:00 on Mon-Fri.

timezone.description: Time zone the schedule should use. Ex "Europe/Stockholm".

qlikSenseTaskId.description: ID of Qlik Sense task that should be started when schedule triggers.

startupState.description: If set to "start" or "started", the schedule will be started upon creation. Otherwise it will remain in stopped state.

tags.description: Can be used to categorise schedules.

cronSchedule.description:
5 or 6 position cron schedule.

If 6 positions used, the leftmost position represent seconds.
If 5 positions used, leftmost position is minutes.

The example schedule will trigger at 00 and 30 minutes past 6:00 on Mon-Fri.

timezone.description: Time zone the schedule should use. Ex "Europe/Stockholm".

qlikSenseTaskId.description: ID of Qlik Sense task that should be started when schedule triggers.

startupState.description: If set to "start" or "started", the schedule will be started upon creation. Otherwise it will remain in stopped state.

tags.description: Can be used to categorise schedules.

lastKnownState.description: Last known state of the schedule

put.description: Start a schedule, i.e. have the scheduler run the associated reload task according to the schedule's cron settings.

200.description:
Schedule successfully started.

An object with all information about the started schedule is returned.

schema.description:
Schedule successfully started.

An object with all information about the started schedule is returned.

cronSchedule.description:
5 or 6 position cron schedule.

If 6 positions used, the leftmost position represent seconds.
If 5 positions used, leftmost position is minutes.

The example schedule will trigger at 00 and 30 minutes past 6:00 on Mon-Fri.

timezone.description: Time zone the schedule should use. Ex "Europe/Stockholm".

qlikSenseTaskId.description: ID of Qlik Sense task that should be started when schedule triggers.

startupState.description: If set to "start" or "started", the schedule will be started upon creation. Otherwise it will remain in stopped state.

tags.description: Can be used to categorise schedules.

lastKnownState.description: Last known state (started/stopped) for the schedule.

put.description: Start all schedules, i.e. tell the scheduler to run each schedule and start associated tasks according to each schedule's settings.

200.description:
Schedules successfully started.

An array with all information about the started schedules is returned.

schema.description:
Schedules successfully started.

An array with all information about the started schedules is returned.

cronSchedule.description:
5 or 6 position cron schedule.

If 6 positions used, the leftmost position represent seconds.
If 5 positions used, leftmost position is minutes.

The example schedule will trigger at 00 and 30 minutes past 6:00 on Mon-Fri.

timezone.description: Time zone the schedule should use. Ex "Europe/Stockholm".

qlikSenseTaskId.description: ID of Qlik Sense task that should be started when schedule triggers.

startupState.description: If set to "start" or "started", the schedule will be started upon creation. Otherwise it will remain in stopped state.

tags.description: Can be used to categorise schedules.

put.description: Stop a schedule, i.e. tell the scheduler to no longer execute the schedule according to its cron settings.

200.description:
Schedule successfully stopped.

An object with all information about the stopped schedule is returned.

schema.description:
Schedule successfully stopped.

An object with all information about the stopped schedule is returned.

cronSchedule.description:
5 or 6 position cron schedule.

If 6 positions used, the leftmost position represent seconds.
If 5 positions used, leftmost position is minutes.

The example schedule will trigger at 00 and 30 minutes past 6:00 on Mon-Fri.

timezone.description: Time zone the schedule should use. Ex "Europe/Stockholm".

qlikSenseTaskId.description: ID of Qlik Sense task that should be started when schedule triggers.

startupState.description: If set to "start" or "started", the schedule will be started upon creation. Otherwise it will remain in stopped state.

tags.description: Can be used to categorise schedules.

lastKnownState.description: Last known state (started/stopped) for the schedule.

put.description: Stop all schedules, i.e. tell the scheduler to no longer execute any schedule according to its cron settings.

200.description:
Schedules successfully stopped.

An array with all information about the stopped schedules is returned.

schema.description:
Schedules successfully stopped.

An array with all information about the stopped schedules is returned.

cronSchedule.description:
5 or 6 position cron schedule.

If 6 positions used, the leftmost position represent seconds.
If 5 positions used, leftmost position is minutes.

The example schedule will trigger at 00 and 30 minutes past 6:00 on Mon-Fri.

timezone.description: Time zone the schedule should use. Ex "Europe/Stockholm".

qlikSenseTaskId.description: ID of Qlik Sense task that should be started when schedule triggers.

startupState.description: If set to "start" or "started", the schedule will be started upon creation. Otherwise it will remain in stopped state.

tags.description: Can be used to categorise schedules.

get.description:
Get basic status from the core scheduler.

No schedule metadata beyond ID, cron setting and job state will be returned, but as this comes from the core scheduler it is the authorative truth about what jobs are running (and which ones are not).

200.description: Status for all jobs that exist in the core scheduler.

schema.description: Status for all jobs that exist in the core scheduler.

put.summary: Do a stand-alone reload of a Qlik Sense app, without using a task.

reloadMode.description: Reload mode that will be used. 0, 1 or 2. If not specified 0 will be used

partialReload.description: Should a full (=false) or partial (=true) reload be done? If not specified a full reload will be done.

startQSEoWTaskOnSuccess.description: Array of task IDs that should be started when the app has successfully reloaded.

startQSEoWTaskOnFailure.description: Array of task IDs that should be started if the app fails reloading.

get.summary: Dump a Sense app to JSON.

200.description: App dump successful. App metadata returned as JSON.

schema.description: App dump successful. App metadata returned as JSON.

422.description: App not found in  Qlik Sense.

schema.description: App not found in  Qlik Sense.

get.summary: Dump a Sense app to JSON.

200.description: App dump successful. App metadata returned as JSON.

schema.description: App dump successful. App metadata returned as JSON.

422.description: App not found in  Qlik Sense.

schema.description: App not found in  Qlik Sense.

get.summary: Get a list of all apps in Sense environment.

200.description: App list successfully retrieved.

get.summary: Get a list of all apps in Sense environment.

200.description: App list successfully retrieved.

put.description:
An optional array of zero or more objects can be passed in the message body. It is used to pass additional info related to the reload task being started.

Currently supported values in this array are:

- A key-value pair that will be stored in Butler's KV store. If Butler's key-value store is not enabled, any key-value information passed in this parameter will simply be ignored.
Setting `ttl=0` disables the TTL feature, i.e. the KV pair will not expire.
- A task identified by its taskId that should be started.
- Tasks identified by tags set on tasks in the QMC.
- Tasks identified by custom properties set in the QMC.

This parameter uses a generic JSON/object format (type + payload).
It's thus possible to add new integrations in future Butler versions.

parameters.description:
If set to `true`, all specified taskIds must exist. If one or more taskIds does not exist in the Sense server, *no* tasks will be started.

If set to `false`, all existing taskIds will be started. Missing/invalid taskIds will be ignored.

In either case, missing/invalid taskIds will be reported in the result set back to the client calling the API.

Note: Tasks started by specifying tags and/or custom properties are not affected by this.
parameters.name: allTaskIdsMustExist

parameters.description:
ID of Qlik Sense task.
Butler will ignore the "magic" task ID of "-" (=dash, hyphen). This ID will not be reported as invalid.
parameters.name: taskId

200.description: Task successfully started.

post.description:
An optional array of zero or more objects can be passed in the message body. It is used to pass additional info related to the reload task being started.

Currently supported values in this array are:

- A key-value pair that will be stored in Butler's KV store. If Butler's key-value store is not enabled, any key-value information passed in this parameter will simply be ignored.
Setting `ttl=0` disables the TTL feature, i.e. the KV pair will not expire.
- A task identified by its taskId that should be started.
- Tasks identified by tags set on tasks in the QMC.
- Tasks identified by custom properties set in the QMC.

This parameter uses a generic JSON/object format (type + payload).
It's thus possible to add new integrations in future Butler versions.

parameters.description:
If set to `true`, all specified taskIds must exist. If one or more taskIds does not exist in the Sense server, *no* tasks will be started.

If set to `false`, all existing taskIds will be started. Missing/invalid taskIds will be ignored.

In either case, missing/invalid taskIds will be reported in the result set back to the client calling the API.

Note: Tasks started by specifying tags and/or custom properties are not affected by this.
parameters.name: allTaskIdsMustExist

parameters.description:
ID of Qlik Sense task.
Butler will ignore the "magic" task ID of "-" (=dash, hyphen). This ID will not be reported as invalid.
parameters.name: taskId

200.description: Task successfully started.

put.description: Sends a basic message to Slack.

channel.description: Slack channel to post message into. Prefix channel name with #.

from_user.description: Name of sending user, as shown in the Slack message

msg.description: Text going into the Slack message
msg.example: This is a message from Qlik Sense

emoji.description: Emoji to shown next to Slack message

msg.description: Text going into the Slack message

emoji.description: Emoji to shown next to Slack message
